citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The licensee used a tube of expired Neosporin ointment to treat an injured, adult female Syrian hamster for fight wounds
(without veterinary consultation). The injured hamster exhibited overt signs of pain, an extensive wound and lameness
during the inspection. The expiration date on the tube is 07/2019. The licensee disposed of the expired ointment at the
time of inspection.
Administering expired medications to animals is not considered a safe or appropriate method to prevent or treat diseases
and injuries because expired drugs may be contaminated, ineffective or produce other undesired effects. Animals may
experience discomfort or distress due to unrelieved symptoms or unexpected side effects from the use of expired
medication. Adequate veterinary care shall include the use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat
diseases and injuries. This includes following established procedures to ensure expired medications are removed and
cannot be administered to animals.
CORRECTED AT THE TIME OF INSPECTION

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
There is an adult, female Syrian hamster separated from the other hamsters due to fighting that the licensee stated
occurred "a couple of days ago." There is an area approximately 1.25" in diameter on the right side of the neck, extending
upward onto the right side of the face and downward to the margin of the right shoulder, where the hair is mostly gone
and the skin is red and puffy in appearance. There is a depressed area on the neck approximately 0.75"X0.24" in area
that is yellow to tan in color with thick yellow material crusted over it. The animal does not bear weight on the right front
limb when walking; it actively turns to hide its wound, away from observers. The hamster hunches while sitting, with the
right forelimb held inward and upward close to the chest; it exhibits squinting and holds its ears backward, with the
margins curled inward. The licensee stated that she treated the wound with Neosporin ointment and presented the tube to
the inspector. The tube was smudged with brown material and the expiration date reads 07/2019. There is no provision in
the Program of Veterinary care for the licensee to perform this treatment, and the license told the inspector she did not
consult with the veterinarian regarding the animal's condition. As the wound appeared significant and the animal
demonstrated signs of pain and lameness, the inspector requested the licensee call the veterinarian immediately for
instructions; the licensee also texted photos to the veterinary at that time. The veterinary clinic advised the licensee to
bring the animal to the clinic in the morning.
Failure to promptly seek and follow the advice of the attending veterinarian when animals are observed to be sick or
injured can result in their prolonged suffering and/or death. The licensee must engage in direct and frequent
communication with the veterinarian when needed, so that timely and accurate information on problems of animal health,
behavior and well-being are communicated to the attending veterinarian.
CORRECTED BY CONTACTING THE VETERINARIAN ON THE DATE OF INSPECTION AND BRINGING THE ANIMAL
TO THE VET BY 2:00PM ON 12/11/2025

An acquisition record for one female and one male coatimundi is incomplete; there is no license number or driver's license
number and state for the seller, and the licensee did not have this information available in other records when asked. The
licensee believed the seller to be licensed with the USDA, and called to obtain the information when asked during the
inspection.
Complete acquisition records are needed to ensure the appropriate acquisition and humane use of animals; the licensee
must ensure that records include the USDA license or registration number of the person from whom animals are acquired,
if he or she is licensed or registered under the Animal Welfare Act.
CORRECTED AT THE TIME OF INSPECTION

Five adult guinea pigs are housed in an enclosure comprised of plexiglass and unsealed wood and particle board; the
back inside wall and floor of the enclosure have areas that appear damp and discolored with urine and feces that
penetrate the wood.
Surfaces that cannot be cleaned and disinfected contribute to an unhealthy environment for the animals because they can
harbor harmful microbes, attract pests and vermin, and release fumes that can be irritating or harmful to the animals. The
licensee must ensure that enclosures, including their racks, shelving and other accessories, are constructed of smooth
material that is substantially impervious to liquids and moisture.
TO BE CORRECTED BY 12/15/2025

In two indoor enclosures containing a total of six adult rabbits, there is a thick sheet of particle board between the bottoms
of the enclosures and the shaved wood bedding. The outside edges of the boards are damp and discolored with urine and
feces that penetrate the wood, and there is a moderately strong ammonia/fecal odor. Surfaces that cannot be cleaned
and disinfected contribute to an unhealthy environment for the animals because they can harbor harmful microbes, attract
pests and vermin, and release fumes that can be irritating or harmful to the animals. The licensee must ensure that
interior surfaces of indoor housing facilities are constructed and maintained so that they are substantially impervious to
moisture and may be readily sanitized.
TO BE CORRECTED BY 12/15/2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Critical
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The licensee used a tube of expired Neosporin ointment to treat an injured, adult female Syrian hamster for fight wounds 
(without veterinary consultation). The injured hamster exhibited overt signs of pain, an extensive wound and lameness

cannot be administered to animals.

3.28(a)(1) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
Five adult guinea pigs are housed in an enclosure comprised of plexiglass and unsealed wood and particle board; the 
back inside wall and floor of the enclosure have areas that appear damp and discolored with urine and feces that 
penetrate the wood.  
Surfaces that cannot be cleaned and disinfected contribute to an unhealthy environment for the animals because they can

3.51(d) 
   
Facilities, indoor. 
In two indoor enclosures containing a total of six adult rabbits, there is a thick sheet of particle board between the bottoms 
of the enclosures and the shaved wood bedding. The outside edges of the boards are damp and discolored with urine and 
feces that penetrate the wood, and there is a moderately strong ammonia/fecal odor. Surfaces that cannot be cleaned 
and disinfected contribute to an unhealthy environment for the animals because they can harbor harmful microbes, attract

interior surfaces of indoor housing facilities are constructed and maintained so that they are substantially impervious to 
moisture and may be readily sanitized. 
TO BE CORRECTED BY 12/15/2025

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
